hierarchy.title: ğŸ“š LEARNING MOMENT: AWS IoT Resource Hierarchy
hierarchy.content: AWS IoT uses a hierarchical structure to organize devices: Thing Types (templates) define device categories, Thing Groups provide organizational structure, and Things represent actual devices. This hierarchy enables scalable device management, bulk operations, and policy inheritance across your IoT fleet.
hierarchy.next: We will create sample resources to demonstrate this hierarchy

thing_groups.title: ğŸ“š LEARNING MOMENT: Thing Groups - Device Organization
thing_groups.content: Thing Groups provide hierarchical organization for your IoT devices, similar to folders for files. They enable bulk operations, policy inheritance, and logical grouping by location, function, or business criteria. Groups can contain other groups, creating flexible organizational structures for large IoT deployments.
thing_groups.next: We will create Thing Groups for device organization

things.title: ğŸ“š LEARNING MOMENT: Things - Device Registration
things.content: Things represent your actual IoT devices in AWS IoT Core. Each Thing has a unique name, optional attributes (like serial number, location), and can be assigned to a Thing Type for standardization. Things are the foundation for device management, security policies, and shadow state synchronization.
things.next: We will create individual Things with realistic attributes

relationships.title: ğŸ“š LEARNING MOMENT: Thing-Group Relationships
relationships.content: Adding Things to Groups creates organizational relationships that enable bulk operations and policy inheritance. A Thing can belong to multiple groups, and groups can be nested. This hierarchy is essential for managing device fleets at scale, applying policies, and organizing devices by business logic.
relationships.next: We will assign Things to appropriate Groups
